data.title: Clear buffered output on output clear event
data.body: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12056

data.title: Output channel buffering ignores channel clearing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: any

Steps to Reproduce:

``` javascript
channel.appendLine('Should never see this');
// sync or async within 300 ms
channel.clear();
channel.appendLine('Should only see this');
```

results in 

```
Should never see this
Should only see this
```

data.title: Relative Line Number support
data.body:
Adds support for vim-style relative line numbers.

Useful for vim motion plugins, replacing extension "Relative Line Numbers" by extr0py.
- word-wrapping aware
- adds `editor.relativeLineNumbers` option (changeable without restart), default to false
- current line is absolute, others are relative (behaviour of hybrid relative numbers in vim)

data.title: Is there any shortcuts to switch between editors and the integrated terminal.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: win 10, 64 bit

My qustion is that is there any shortcuts to switch between editors and the integrated terminal? Here I can  only use the CTRL+1, CTRL+2... to switch the open editor tabs.

data.title: Add "Reveal in Explorer", "Copy path", etc actions to the context menu of the tabs as well

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012R2

Steps to Reproduce:

Currently the "Reveal in Explorer", "Copy path", etc actions are only shown in the context menu of items in the Explorer sidebar. When I'm not in a workspace I usually have this bar closed to save screenspace, so opening it just to do one of these actions is annoying. It would be nice if all these actions were also present in the context menu of the tabs themselves.

![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1096010/18534934/d3f00b6a-7aa4-11e6-8d32-0e9e1a2e63be.png)

data.title: [Suggestion] Markdown: Indentation inside code blocks should not affect indentation detection for the rest of the document
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set `editor.tabSize` to `4` and `editor.detectIndentation` to `true`.
2. Create a markdown file with the following contents:
   
   ```
   asdf
       qwer
   
   ***
   asdf
     qwer
   ***
   ```
   
   Replace the \* with markdown backticks so that the second `asdf` and `qwer` are in a code block.
   
   To clarify, the `qwer` outside the code block is indented by a tab character, and the `qwer` inside the code block is indented by 2 spaces.
3. Close and reopen the file to force VSCode to re-render it.
4. The tab that indents the first `qwer` (the one outside the code block) is rendered as two columns wide instead of four columns as the setting specifies. Also, if I add new lines and indent them with <kbd>Tab</kbd> they'll be indented by two spaces, not even a tab.

I hit this while writing a document that embeds code snippets from various locations, and some of those snippets use two spaces for indentation. I want to maintain the original indentation since it's significant, but I also don't want the rest of the document to be affected by it.

data.title: Also prepend closed files to the "Open Recent" list as they're closed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new file, save it as test.txt and close the tab.
2. Look in `File -> Open Recent` - test.txt is not there.

Similarly
1. Open files foo.txt, bar.txt, baz.txt
2. Close foo.txt
3. Look in `File -> Open Recent` - foo.txt is not at the top of the list.

This behavior is present atleast in NPP, and is very useful. Say I have four or five files that I've had open for days, so they've been pushed out of the "Open Recent" list. Now if I close them but then realize I need one of them back, there is no way to reopen it except the long way of "Open File..."

Note that "Reopen closed editor" is not a good solution because the file I want to reopen may not be the last closed file, and also because this menu option gives no indication which file it's going to open when I click it anyway (maybe that's another bug).

data.title: Do not add to recent files list when running with "--diff"
data.body:

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  [Setup vscode as the default difftool for git](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/versioncontrol)
2. Run: `git difftool <commit>^ <commit>`
3. Check recent files list to see it populated with temp files

data.title: Feature Request: Scroll Off

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
In Vim, you can set a scrolloff so it keeps at least N lines below the cursor:

![scrolloff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/18530654/6bb338c8-7a87-11e6-85c7-deab2d060d48.gif)

Currently Code has a scrolloff of 1. Would be great if this is made an option.

data.title: Release 1.5 Quick Open never finishes and Activity Monitor shows high CPU
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Max OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In Visual Studio Code editor, Command P.  Type in a file to search for.  It searches but never finishes.  
2. Open Activity Monitor and it shows find using high cpu 80% and Code Helper using 120%.  
3.  Have to force quit find and Code Helper in order to recover. 

Note: In prior versions I was using Command E and it worked great.  In version 1.5.1 that was taken away so I had to start using Command P and it has never worked the same. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/531028/18530280/d4e2dcec-7a9e-11e6-801e-66b57ddf6e89.png)

data.title: Add support for InsertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingJsxExpressionBraces
data.body:
## Feature Request

**User Scenario**

Steps to Reproduce:
1. TypeScript Version: 2.*
2. `<input value={ this.state.value } />`
3. Format document

**Expected behavior:**
In **1.8.10** the spacing inside the brackets was unchanged on format operation (closing bracket `}` or format document).
`<input value={ this.state.value } />`

**Actual behavior:** 
In **2.**\* the space inside the brackets is always removed when formatting.

``` ts
<input value={this.state.value} />
```

**Discussion**
- [Original Issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11791)
- [Fix on TypeScript's End](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/9361)

Recommendation from @dbaeumer was to have this added to September's milestone.

data.title: The Update feature results in linkage and Default App problems
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an existing installation of vscode and select the Update link
2. Upon updating, note that the newly-downloaded .app file is within the ~/Downloads folder rather than in Applications, making it not readily available for the Launchpad nor to the Open With... lookup within the Finder application.  This will show (only) the previous version of vscode rather than the freshly-downloaded version.
3. Also note that it is typical to "Keep in Docker" something you use a lot, similar to Windows's "Pin this to Taskbar" feature.  After an update the Docker's location is now for an earlier version, causing problems.

data.title: Cant set my prefered font - Terminus (SOLVED)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 ( last version available today - 9/14/16 ) 1.4v also was tested without success.  
- OS Version: Ubuntu, Kali, gentoo, rhel-7.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. apt-get install xfont-terminus
2. Open vscode and try to change font family to "xfont-terminus" or "terminus" or "Terminus" or "ter-u12n.pcf" --- no one is work. I tried a lot of combination with zero success :( 

It is my preferred font and it does not work :( 

I tried manually install terminus font (http://terminus-font.sourceforge.net/) but it does not help. All others app (vim, teminator, anjuta ... ) recognize terminus font. But not vscode !

data.title: Identical file name path in tab is too long and difficult to diff
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider (fad6a894c197ee791403ac694c9316b0654f31a4, 2016-09-14T13:18:39.616Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-36-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Current:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18524039/a403a33c-7a6b-11e6-94e6-02f60bc61668.png)

Proposed:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18524117/fe9a1f7e-7a6b-11e6-8c73-0d6aac733096.png)

To describe the behavior I want: It should replace all parts of the start of the path that are the same with `/`, then add the differing word(s) and then either `//` or `/`. This makes it easier to differentiate each tab and also reduces the total space taken by the tab particularly in a deep directory structure.

Some interesting cases could arise when more than 2 files collide in which maybe 2 parts of the path would need to be displayed, for example:
- `src/vs/workbench/parts/execution/electron-browser/terminalService.ts`
- `src/vs/workbench/parts/execution/electron-browser/something/terminalService.ts`
- `src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalService.ts`

Could yield:
- `/execution/electron-browser/terminalService.ts`
- `/execution/electron-browser/something/terminalService.ts`
- `/terminal//terminalService.ts`

Basically just providing enough information to uniquely identify the file, `electron-browser` could not be truncated above as `/execution//terminalService.ts` represents both files.

Another interesting edge case: single letter folders would probably consume more space when truncated.

data.title: Env variables are not set while working with externalTerminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1 (07d663dc1bd848161edf4cd4ce30cce410d3d877)
- OS Version: Mac Os 10.11.5 (15F34) El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. make python script

```
import os
print os.getenv('test_key')
```
1. make run configuration

```
{
            "name": "test",
            "type": "python",
            "request": "launch",
            "pythonPath": "${config.python.pythonPath}",
            "program": "/path/to/test.py",
            "console": "externalTerminal",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [
                "-v"
            ],
            "env": {
                "test_key": "1"
            },
            "debugOptions": [
                "WaitOnNormalExit",
                "RedirectOutput"
            ]
        }
```
1. Launch

Expected result: 1 will be printed
Actual result: None will be printed

More: with integratedTerminal works fine

data.title: Split intellisense icon sprite
Save file to disk even if not changed when saving

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Maybe this is more of a feature request, but I would like the editor to touch the saved file even though there has not been any change in the contents of the file. This is useful in a scenario where for example a test is run when you save/change a file. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. save unchanged file
2. observe file not being touched
- VSCode Version: 1.52
- OS Version: Win 10 64bit
